snippet: Mike Castellani, the “audio engineer” for the Mets since 1994, and others discuss the work and thought that go into that snippet of music that accompanies a player to the plate or pitcher’s mound.
abstract: Major League Baseball's at-bat and entrance music has transformed into a player-driven phenomenon that can be more complicated than it appears; Mike Castellani, audio engineer for the Mets discusses changes and challenges that he and other sound engineers in baseball face.
lead_paragraph: Mike Castellani, the “audio engineer” for the Mets since 1994, and others discuss the work and thought that go into that snippet of music that accompanies a player to the plate or pitcher’s mound.

headline.main: Enter Sound Man: An Insider’s Look at Baseball’s Walk-Up Music
headline.print_headline: Modern Hitters Rely on Quick Hands (Of Home Ballparks’ Audio Engineers)
